body: LUCHINS--Dr. Abraham S. 91, on December 27, 2005. A prolific researcher and author, pioneer Gestalt psychologist, Founding Chairman of the Psychology Departments at Yeshiva College and
title: Paid Notice: Deaths LUCHINS, DR. ABRAHAM S.

body: The big black Town Car was a money machine, and there was a pink air freshener hanging from the gearshift and another from the rear-view. title: TRANSIT STRIKE: BROOKLYN; Streets Paved With Fares For Tireless Livery Driver

body: Shivering, intrepid and occasionally befuddled, New Yorkers yesterday faced down the first citywide transit strike in a quarter-century, walking, biking and car-pooling through their city as transit workers and the state agency that employs them remained locked in intransigence. Millions of subway and bus commuters stood at street corners,
title: TRANSIT STRIKE: OVERVIEW; STRIKE HALTS NEW YORK SUBWAYS AND BUSES; CITY SCRAMBLES AS UNION IS HIT WITH BIG FINE

body: BUNTING the color of a bad bruise draped the Tropical Paradise Restaurant in East Flatbush yesterday. It was hung in memory of Police Officer Dillon Stewart, who used to eat breakfast there, but now lay dead in a coffin in the church across the street. The black-and-purple fabric that rippled in the chilly Brooklyn air also reflected the smallness
title: About New York; For Police Officer and City, A Wound to the Heart

Inside, the grief-stricken widow, the two children, the friends, the relatives and all the others remembered a life
title: Mourning a Fallen Officer, and Paying Tribute to a 'True Hero'

title: Dress Blues and Salutes for Fallen Officer

body: A Brooklyn grand jury yesterday indicted Allan Cameron, the man prosecutors say killed a New York City police officer on Monday and robbed and shot an off-duty officer on Nov. 19. The cases will be heard separately in State Supreme Court, law enforcement officials said. Mr. Cameron's charges include first-degree murder for the killing of the
title: Suspect in Police Officer's Killing Is Indicted

body: When two officers turned on their turret light and siren and pulled a U-turn on a Brooklyn street early Monday, they most likely had no inkling that they might be trailing a man who had reasons to resist being caught. The driver, Allan Cameron, was wanted for assaulting officers in Pennsylvania two years ago, had 53 small bags of marijuana in his
title: Suspect's History With Police Emerges at Hearing

body: A New York City police officer pursuing a driver in Brooklyn was fatally shot through the heart early yesterday when the driver fired five bullets into the officer's patrol car, officials said. In spite of his wound, the officer kept driving for blocks in pursuit of the gunman. The officer, Dillon Stewart, 35, was then taken in his own
title: OFFICER IS KILLED AFTER PULLING UP NEXT TO GUNMAN

body: When the 30-year-old accountant at WNYC told his co-workers at the public radio station that he was leaving his job of nine years for a new career, they were shocked. ''He said, 'I want to become a police officer,' '' said Brenda Williams-Butts, 46, director of community affairs. ''Why?'' she asked him. ''It's just something I want to do,'' she
title: An Accountant Changed Careers at 30, and the Citations for Bravery Followed

body: Five men were shot in three separate, apparently unrelated incidents in the same Brooklyn precinct yesterday, leaving two dead and two in critical condition, the police said. Two of the shootings occurred less than 10 minutes apart in Brownsville last evening. The first, near 96th Street and Clarkson Avenue, took place just before 5:15 p.m., when
title: On a Single Day in One Precinct, Five Men Are Shot, Two Fatally

body: He walked these avenues and then he was gone, as the inhabitants of one city give way to the next, as some are hurried along. Everyone leaves behind a name, a time, a place and a role, and his were Jimmy Moy, 1960, Park Slope, Brooklyn: the man who never returned. A cataclysm's sudden vacancy leaves the memory of the disappeared, and the great
title: Tracing Steps of the Man Who Walked Away

body: WE owe the existence of Brooklyn to the urban developers of more than a century ago. Since that time, the borough's open land has disappeared. But just as we'll always have developers, community activists and environmentalists will invariably seek to check their greed and
title: The Project That Ate Brooklyn

title: Brooklyn Teenager Is Stabbed to Death

body: IT was probably only a matter of time before the big three big-box retailers -- Wal-Mart, Kmart and Target -- got interested in selling furniture. title: SQUARE FEET; Towers Grow in Downtown Brooklyn

body: FOR many American Jews, kugel is the taste of childhood. They want exactly the kind of kugel their mother made, whether it is a weekly Sabbath treat or served only on holidays like Rosh Hashana, which starts on Monday night. I didn't know until recently, though, that this homey casserole of noodles or potatoes was credited with mystical powers.
title: Kugel Unraveled

title: GOOD EATING/PROSPECT HEIGHTS; Ahead of the Bounce

body: Names With a Past Q. Could you tell me where these trains used to go? A. Sure, but first, a romantic aside.
title: F. Y. I.

title: NEIGHBORHOODS; Craving Hyphenated Chinese

title: Buying Is Easy Owning Is Hard

title: 5 Shootings In 10 Hours Leave 5 Dead

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PROSPECT HEIGHTS; Mama's Gone, Along With The Peach Cobbler

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; Risks and Rewards Of Art in the Open

title: Candidates Criticize Bloomberg's Use of City's Money

body: WHEN my doorbell rings, the two brothers chime in unison, ''Your slipcovers!'' Hirschel, 77, wears a Russian fur hat, and says loudly, in brief bursts, like Grandpa from ''The Munsters,'' ''Your slipcovers are ready!'' Archie, 82, carries the slipcovers over his arm. ''We don't make a mess this time,'' he solemnly promises. In the family room, the
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Their Own Little Ottoman Empire

body: A Brooklyn man burst into a basement apartment in Flatlands yesterday, fatally stabbing a 53-year-old woman and her dog and slashing the woman's 16-year-old niece in the face, the police said. The man, Pierre Carrenard, 35, had been stalking the dead woman's daughter, Macdaly François, 25, since she broke up with him a couple of months ago,
title: Brooklyn Woman Killed by Her Daughter's Ex-Boyfriend, Police Say

title: Building the Béisbol Brand

title: THE SUMMER COOK; Easing The Way To Dinner

title: 4 Are Killed and 6 Hurt in 4 Gun Attacks

title: Man Shot Ex-Girlfriend as Children Played Nearby, Police Say

body: LONG before the BlackBerry and the PlayStation Portable, New Yorkers loved their hand-helds. The folded pizza slice, the hot dog and the crusty knish have a built-in mobility that lets hungry New Yorkers eat on the street, and enough density to carry them through to the next meal. New immigrants have added to the on-the-go family, introducing
title: Jamaican Passions

body: JAMAICAN drinks can sneak up on you. Ginger beer is a good place to start, the slow burn of the ginger acting as a cooler in hot weather. From there it's an easy jump to spicy, ruby red sorrel punch tart enough to stand up to the delicious fat in a meat patty. But read to the bottom of the menu at New York's Jamaican patty stands and juice bars.
title: Thirst Quenchers and Man Drinks

body: Sipping her morning coffee, Karen Bornarth stared with amazement yesterday at the new building plan that would create a towering row of skyscrapers around a proposed Nets arena east of Downtown Brooklyn, and forever change the borough's cozy skyline. ''The idea of having a sports team in Brooklyn is nice,'' said Ms. Bornarth, a 34-year-old baker,
title: Brooklynites Take In a Big Development Plan, and Speak Up

body: The massive building plan surrounding a new Nets arena east of Downtown Brooklyn will include a ridge of a half-dozen skyscrapers as high as 60 stories sweeping down Atlantic Avenue, along with four towers circling the basketball arena, according to new designs completed by the developer Bruce C. Ratner and the architect Frank Gehry. The project,
title: Instant Skyline Added to Brooklyn Arena Plan

body: Frank Gehry's new design for a 21-acre corridor of high-rise towers anchored by the 19,000-seat Nets arena in Brooklyn may be the most important urban development plan proposed in New York City in decades. If it is approved, it will radically alter the Brooklyn skyline, reaffirming the borough's emergence as a legitimate cultural rival to
title: AN APPRAISAL; Seeking First to Reinvent the Sports Arena, and Then Brooklyn

body: A Brooklyn teenager was arraigned yesterday on murder charges in the killing of a 15-year-old boy, who the authorities say was stabbed to death after more than a dozen youngsters set upon him and three friends and stole an iPod from one of them. The teenager, Darran Samuel, 16, was ordered held without bail at his arraignment before Criminal Court
title: Brooklyn Youth Denied Bail In Killing During IPod Theft

body: HERMAN--Amy. 53, on July 2. Beloved daughter of Sylvia, sister of Marc, sister-in-law of Harriet, aunt, friend and colleague of many. Amy contributed to the well being of this city through her passionate work in legal services, the NY AIDS Coalition, and most recently, for the National Organizational Development Network. She fought cancer for more
title: Paid Notice: Deaths HERMAN, AMY

body: A Colorful Holiday, Buzzing in the Bronx The red, white and blue will fly at the Bronx Zoo this weekend, and not just on the American flag. title: Family Fare

body: The 30-second encounter in Brooklyn began with that most routine form of morning commerce, the breakfast pastry purchase. Almost instantly, the scene inside a Dunkin' Donuts shop on Empire Boulevard in Flatbush turned ugly. The customer pulled a knife and lunged toward the clerk's face and, with his other hand, tried to reach into the cash
title: Morning Action at the Doughnut Shop: A Robbery Attempt Is Caught on Camera

author: Jenny Allen is a contributing editor at Good Housekeeping and a stand-up comic.
body: MY friend Ashton and her boyfriend, Bob, are leaving Ashton's roomy, prewar apartment on West End Avenue and buying a two-story house in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. They are not making a real estate killing, the only reason I would consider budging from the Upper West Side. Like many of my fellow middle-aged Upper West Siders, I am hanging on for dear
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/BACKLASH; They'll Take Manhattan

author: Suketu Mehta is the author of ''Maximum City: Bombay Lost and Found'' (Knopf).
body: AT a party on the Upper West Side in 2000, a distinguished American author, and longtime Manhattanite, asked where I lived. ''Brooklyn,'' I told him. He snorted. ''Poor people live in Brooklyn.'' Then he turned away to get some meat. Shortly after the party, to see if I could move from my rented apartment in Boerum Hill, I went looking to see what
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/SIGNS OF CHANGING TIMES; The Great Awakening

author: Humera Afridi is completing her first novel, ''Asymptotes,'' set in New York, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia.
body: CONEY ISLAND is what they call it. ''Our new home -- Coney Island,'' they say proudly and flick their eyes toward the double-wide avenue lined with squat two- and three-story buildings huddled together like members of an ambushed army. The short stretch of Coney Island Avenue from Avenue H to Beverly Road, along with the side streets leading off
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/FACES OF A BOROUGH; The Coney Island Of Their Mind

body: A Founding Mother Q. I recently read that Gravesend, Brooklyn, was founded by a woman back in the 17th century, which seems early for a woman to have had such a civic role. Is this true? A. Not only is it true, an interesting tale lies behind it, one that reminds us that religious tolerance was not uniformly practiced in the Colonies. Gravesend,
title: F.Y.I.

author: Susan Choi is the author, most recently, of "American Woman," a novel.
body: THEY'RE one of the things I most treasure about Brooklyn, by far its most exotic species. And you don't need to expend extraordinary effort to find them. You don't need sensitive recording devices. You don't need a kayak. Despite all this, few people notice them. Is this because they're such quintessential Brooklynites themselves? For one thing,
title: VOICES; 'Who Needs Myth When We Have the Real Thing?'

title: HABITATS/Midwood, Brooklyn; Discovering You Can Go Home Again

title: Years Later, a Final Goodbye to a Firefighter Lost on 9/11

title: SQUARE FEET/Cortelyou Road, Brooklyn; A Commercial Strip Gaining in Charm

title: FOOD STUFF; Still More Goodies For Brooklyn Neighborhoods

Standing in front of a window in the shop he opened 15 years ago, Creative Needle Tailoring, Mr. Mustafa said he was dreading the loss of the crown jewel of the strip
title: A Separation Sets In: No Brides, No Business?

title: Racial Politics of 2001; Unhealed Wounds in 2005

body: To the Editor: ''The Spell of the El'' (May 1) accepts the New York City Transit position that none of the three deadliest subway disasters occurred on elevated lines. title: Brooklyn's Elevated Train Disaster

title: Grisly Discovery Near Train Tracks

title: LIVING IN/Prospect Park South, Brooklyn; Near Prospect Park, a Touch of Greenwich

body: THE end came abruptly on Third Avenue. Just after 6 p.m. on May 12, 1955, the last elevated uptown train rolled out of Chatham Square, in Chinatown, bound for the Bronx and then for incineration. Subway ridership had declined steadily after peaking at 2.1 billion in 1947. Elevated railways, at least in Manhattan, were seen as a thing of the past.
title: The Spell Of the El

body: This is about dining out. Not in one of those fancy food palaces where the maître d'hôtel stands in judgment at a celestial podium and the reservations are only available at 5:30 -- handed out like condescending early-bird specials. No, this is about a new global dining phenomenon in which you have to know somebody who knows somebody just to find
title: Psst ... Alice Waters Sent Me

body: Could you borrow a painting or sculpture from your local library? It's not very likely. Libraries are, as conventional wisdom suggests, about books rather than art objects. title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; On a Treasure Hunt for Art Stashed Among the Books

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Minister Accused In Sexual Abuse Of Boy

body: IN the narrow kitchen of his apartment on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, Andrew Feinberg was about to make clam pizza. That might sound like a perfectly quotidian pastime for Mr. Feinberg, since he is the chef and an owner of Franny's restaurant, a favorite among New York pizza fans. But truth is, he'd never made pizza at home. In fact before opening
title: THE CHEF: ANDREW FEINBERG; A Student of the Pizza Does a Little Homework

She would enroll at Brooklyn College starting in February 1941. The campus lay two hours and several transfers
title: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF; A Journey, a Headline And an Urban Villager

author: Jessica Grose is an M.F.A. candidate at Columbia and the editorial assistant at Spin.com. She lives in Brooklyn.
body: SINCE I know what it's like to sob on nearly every single form of public transportation in the New York metropolitan area, I can tell you with authority that crying on the subway is the most cathartic. I suppose I'm not a full-fledged expert in local mass transit emoting; I have yet to cry on the Staten Island Ferry or the tram to Roosevelt Island.
title: MODERN LOVE; Me? I'm Just Fine (Whimper). Really (Sob).

body: It could have been spring fever. But whatever whimsy led five 15-year-old boys to act out a bank robbery yesterday in the lobby of a Brooklyn savings and loan, it probably dissipated with their arrest. ''They were being kids,'' said one police official, who insisted that his name not be used. In the end, two of the boys were charged with attempted
title: Bank Math: Dose of Spring Fever + 1 Bad Joke = 5 Arrests

body: FROM penthouse apartments in Manhattan to 19th-century brownstones in Brooklyn, and from tiny backyard spaces to bulging community gardens, the spring season of show houses and house and garden tours has begun in New York City. This year's sampling includes private modern art collections, shiny new kitchens, lush plantings and antiques galore.
title: Spring Ambles In, Along With the Curious

body: In the last decade, the number of rent-regulated apartments in New York City has been gradually diminishing. title: The Slow Fadeout of Rent Regulated Apartments

title: Remains Found Under Garage In Brooklyn

title: Dance's Vanguard Stakes Out Brooklyn

title: Hundreds of Rallies Held Across U.S. to Protest Iraq War

title: The Guide

body: From its inception, the Paramount Theater in downtown Brooklyn was a knockout. Starting in 1928, it welcomed guests into its mirrored lobby and its impossibly ornate playhouse, where Miles Davis, Ethel Merman, Bing Crosby and Mae West performed under innumerable golden statues and fountains spewing dry ice. A Wurlitzer organ, second in size only to
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; Yet Another New Chapter For a Glamorous Old Theater

title: Transplanted, a Russian Savors the Freedom to Dare

title: STREETSCAPES/Brooklyn; Can Nearly Half a Building Add Up to a Landmark?

title: Arthur Miller, Moral Voice Of American Stage, Dies at 89

title: Spare Times

body: A police officer helped deliver a baby last night -- for the 10th time in his 20-year career, the police said. The officer, Scott Lothrop, was helping a driver on the shoulder of the Belt Parkway near the Flatbush Avenue exit at 6 p.m. when another driver pulled over, said that his wife was in labor and asked to be escorted to the hospital, said
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer Helps Deliver Baby, Again

body: The police arrested a man yesterday in the killing of an Army sergeant outside a nightclub in Brooklyn on Sunday morning, the authorities said. The man, Joseph Carrington, 24, of 130 Martense Street in Flatbush, was charged with second-degree murder, attempted murder and first-degree assault, the police said. The shooting outside the nightclub,
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arrest In Nightclub Killing

body: The police identified a suspect yesterday in the killing of an Army sergeant outside a nightclub in Brooklyn on Sunday morning, and said the gunman may have fired simply because he saw the sergeant talking to his girlfriend. The suspect, Joseph Carrington, 24, lives at 130 Martense Street in Flatbush, the police said. There is a $2,000 reward for
title: Suspect Named In Fatal Shooting Outside a Club

body: REDDOCK--Judith. Beloved wife of Philip (dec.). Loving mother of Jason and Carol (Howard). Adored ''Bubbe'' of Lauren and Ross. Dear sister of Estelle and Honey. Funeral Monday, January 10, 11:30 am, IJ Morris Funeral Directors, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths REDDOCK, JUDITH

author: E-mail: eating@nytimes.com
body: Holiday decorations are coming down as New York settles into its gray season. But these Caribbean places add brightness to the restaurant scene. BOHIO (212) 568-5029; 4055 Broadway (171st Street); $; $25 and Under: 2/4/04. This friendly Dominican restaurant offers ''Viejo Latino'' cuisine with a stylish twist, like chunks of pernil, or roasted pork
title: GOOD EATING; Caribbean Lights
